meanings.definition: To wear away or erode by corrosion.
meanings.sent1: The salty water was slowly corrading the metal railing by the beach.
meanings.sent2: The old pipes in the house were corrading due to years of neglect.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous squirrels seemed to enjoy corrading the bird feeder with their sharp teeth.
meanings.sent4: Time seemed to be corrading the memories of their childhood like rust on an old car.
meanings.sent5: The relentless waves corrading the cliffs created a stunning natural sculpture over time.

meanings.sent1: The metal gate started corrading after being exposed to the harsh elements.
meanings.sent2: The statue in the park was slowly corrading, losing its shine over the years.
meanings.sent3: The abandoned ship seemed to be corrading away into the sea, becoming part of the underwater world.
meanings.sent4: His trust in people was slowly corrading, like a castle crumbling under siege.
meanings.sent5: The once vibrant colors of the painting were now corrading into muted tones, a sign of age and wear.

meanings.sent1: The factory had to shut down due to the corrading of its machinery, causing a halt in production.
meanings.sent2: The slow corrading of the bridge's support beams raised concerns about its structural integrity.
meanings.sent3: The comedic play highlighted the absurdity of the corrading process with exaggerated sound effects.
meanings.sent4: The corrading of trust between the two friends left a rift that seemed impossible to mend.
meanings.sent5: The artist captured the beauty in the corrading of metal, turning decay into art.
